quizzes.question:
What is the output of this code?
a = 25
b = 8
x = a/b
puts x+b
quizzes.textContent:
[h1]Doing Math[/h1]

Math is an important part of programming. Ruby supports the following[b] arithmetic operators[/b]: [code format="rb" codeId="975"]x = 5
y = 2

[b]# Addition[/b]
puts x+y 
# outputs 7

[b]# Subtraction [/b]
puts x-y 
# outputs 3

[b]# Multiplication[/b]
puts x*y
# outputs 10

[b]# Division[/b]
puts x/y
# outputs 2[/code]
[note]When you divide two integer values, the result will be an integer, as shown in the above example. If you want to have a floating point result, one operand must be a floating point value:
x = 5.0
y = 2
puts x/y # outputs 2.5[/note]

quizzes.question:
What is the value of z?
a = 13
b = a - 8
z = a%b
quizzes.textContent:
[h1]Modulus Operator[/h1]

The [b]modulus [/b]operator, represented by the percentage symbol (%), represents the remainder of a division operation.
[b]For example:[/b][code format="rb" codeId="976"]x = 9
y = 5
puts x%y
# outputs 4[/code]
[note]9 divided by 5 is 1 with a remainder of 4.[/note]

quizzes.question: What is the result of 3**2?
quizzes.textContent:
[h1]Exponent Operator[/h1]

The ** represents the [b]exponent [/b]operator for raising a number to a power to perform exponentiation.
[b]For example:[/b] [code format="rb" codeId="977"]a = 2
b = 5
puts a**b
# this raises 2 to the power of 5 and outputs 32[/code]
The result is 32, as 2*2*2*2*2 = 32.
[note]All operators can also be used with floating point values.[/note]

quizzes.question:
What is the output of this code?
a = 8
a /= 3
puts 4%a
quizzes.textContent:
[h1]Shorthand Assignment Operators[/h1]

All of the arithmetic operators have corresponding shorthand forms for assignment.
For example, a = a + 8 can be written as a += 8. 
The same applies to the other operators: [code format="rb" ]x += y  # x=x+y
x -= y  # x=x-y
x *= y  # x=x*y
x /= y  # x=x/y
x %= y  # x=x%y
x **= y  # x=x**y[/code]
[note]These are called [b]self-assignment[/b] operators, as they perform an assignment and an arithmetic operation at the same time.[/note]

quizzes.question:
Fill in the blanks to swap the values of the variables using a single statement:
[!raw!]
x = 10
y = 42
x, y {0} y{1} x
quizzes.textContent:
[h1]Parallel Assignment[/h1]

Ruby also supports parallel assignment of variables. This enables multiple variables to be initialized with a single line of code. 
[b]For example:[/b] [code format="rb" ]x = 10
y = 20
z = 30[/code]may be more quickly initialized using parallel assignment: [code format="rb" codeId="978"]x, y, z = 10, 20, 30[/code]
[note]Parallel assignment is also useful for swapping the values held in two variables:
a, b = b, a[/note]
